definition: Files created for surviving Revolutionary War veterans who applied for pensions under the various acts, particularly service and invalid pensions. These applications represent veterans’ own claims for pensions.
proof_quote: "The file may also contain affidavits by other veterans or persons testifying to the service or disability claimed; documentary evidence of service submitted by the applicant, such as a commission or a discharge certificate..." (M804 pamphlet, p. 7)

definition: Files for widows of Revolutionary War veterans who applied for pensions based on their husband’s service. Various acts were enacted to provide pensions to widows, often with varying requirements and restrictions. The widow's application may be interfiled with the veteran's original application, or may include mention of a second husband if she remarried.
proof_quote: "Incorporated in or attached to some widows' applications is a copy of a marriage record made by a town clerk, a clergyman, or a justice of the peace. Sometimes family-record pages from Bibles and other books were also submitted by a widow as proof of marriage." (M804 pamphlet, p. 7)

definition: Files of applications by survivors, widows, or an heir that were rejected under pension laws, including those deemed ineligible under service requirements or property tests. Some application files may contain multiple applications for the same veteran, including earlier appeals that were granted. Denials often stemmed from insufficient service, failure to meet marriage-date rules for widows, or results of the 1820 means test.
proof_quote: "The new law [of 1820] required every pensioner receiving payments under the 1818 act, and every would-be pensioner, to submit a certified schedule of his estate and income to the Secretary of War. The Secretary was authorized to remove from the pension list the names of those persons who, in his opinion, were not in need of assistance. Within a few years the total of Revolutionary War service pensioners was reduced by several thousand." (M804 pamphlet, p. 2)

definition: Files documenting claims for bounty land warrants (rights to free land in the public domain) granted instead of, or in addition to, pensions as a reward for military service. Land warrant claims were often intertwined with pension records and sometimes appear interfiled within the main pension series.
proof_quote: "The [1776] resolution specified that each noncommissioned officer and soldier should be entitled to 100 acres, an ensign to 150 acres, each lieutenant to 200 acres, and other officers to proportionate amounts of land up to 500 acres for a colonel. By a resolution of August 12, 1780, the provision was extended to include generals, and the grant was to be 850 acres for a brigadier general and 1,100 acres for a major general.." (M804 pamphlet, p. 5)

definition: An archival label applied to certain early pension files, maintained separately but sometimes interfiled with Revolutionary War records. These represent a filing category, not a single legislative act.
proof_quote: "Some files, for instance, are labeled "Not Rev." or "Not Rev. War" and contain pension or bounty-land-warrant application papers based on post-Revolutionary War service." (M804 pamphlet, p. 10)

definition: N A Acc (National Archives Accession [number]) placeholder cards were sometimes created when no original pension file survived or to refer to another series of pension applications filed separately.
proof_quote: "Some pension application files reproduced in this microcopy have headings that include instructions to "See N.A. Acc. No. 874 " followed by a number between 050000 and 050201, the name of the veteran, and the notation "Half Pay" or "Not Half Pay." These instructions refer to a separate series of pension application files that are also in Record Group 15. " (M804 pamphlet, p. 10)
